column16:
This procedure runs after the account status field (txtAcctStatus) is updated. It controls whether certain fields on the form are enabled or disabled based on the new account status.

Step-by-step explanation
1. If the account status is “Inactive” or “In Runoff”

The form enables:

Termination Date field (txtTermDt)
Termination Cause field (txtTermCause)
Notification Date field (bxNotifDt)


It also sets the focus to the termination cause field and opens its dropdown list so the user can select a reason.


2. If the account status is “Active”

First, it enables the termination fields temporarily so it can clear them.
It sets Termination Date and Termination Cause to Null (empty), removing any previous termination details.
Then it disables those fields because an active account cannot have termination information.
It also disables the Notification Date field.


In short

When the account becomes Inactive or In Runoff, termination-related fields are turned on so the user can fill them.
When the account becomes Active, termination-related fields are cleared and turned off because they don’t apply.

column16:
Trigger: Runs after the form control AcctOwner is updated (i.e., when a new account owner is selected).


A) Update Claim Review distribution (tblDist_ClaimRev_AFFIN)

Initialize objects:

MyDB = CurrentDb(); MyRec opens as an editable dynaset on tblDist_ClaimRev_AFFIN (with dbSeeChanges, dbOptimistic).


Suppress prompts:

DoCmd.SetWarnings False to avoid Access confirmation dialogs during delete/insert.


Remove duplicates for the same program + recipient:

Deletes rows where [ProgramName] & [AttnTo] equals Me.bxAcctName & Me.AcctOwner to prevent duplicate entries.


Housekeeping (null recipients):

Deletes any row in tblDist_ClaimRev_AFFIN where AttnTo is Null.


Add the current selection:

MyRec.AddNew creates a row tied to the current program and owner.
Sets MyRec!ProgramName = Me.bxAcctName.
Sets MyRec!RecipCat = "Account Owner".
Sets MyRec!EMailAddress = Me.AcctOwner.Column(1) (email from the second column of AcctOwner).
Sets MyRec!DistVia = "Email".
Sets MyRec!AttnTo = Me.AcctOwner (the selected owner’s display value).


Commit & cleanup:

MyRec.Update, MyRec.Close, Set MyRec = Nothing.




B) Update Loss Run distribution (tblDist_LossRun_AFFIN)

Initialize objects:

MyDB = CurrentDb(); MyRec opens as an editable dynaset on tblDist_LossRun_AFFIN (with dbSeeChanges, dbOptimistic).


Suppress prompts:

DoCmd.SetWarnings False (warnings already off; calling again is fine).


Remove duplicates for the same program + recipient:

Deletes rows where [ProgramName] & [AttnTo] equals Me.bxAcctName & Me.AcctOwner.


Housekeeping (null recipients):

Deletes any row in tblDist_LossRun_AFFIN where AttnTo is Null.


Add the current selection:

MyRec.AddNew then sets the same fields:

ProgramName = Me.bxAcctName
RecipCat = "Account Owner"
EMailAddress = Me.AcctOwner.Column(1)
DistVia = "Email"
AttnTo = Me.AcctOwner




Commit & cleanup:

MyRec.Update, MyRec.Close, Set MyRec = Nothing.

column16:
Big picture
When you change bxLossCtl1 on the form, this routine:

Removes any duplicate or empty entries in two distribution tables.
Adds a fresh entry to each table using the values currently shown on the form.
It does this twice—first for tblDist_ClaimRev_AFFIN, then for tblDist_LossRun_AFFIN.


Step-by-step (first table: tblDist_ClaimRev_AFFIN)


Get ready to work with the database

MyDB grabs the current database.
MyRec opens a writable view (dynaset) of the tblDist_ClaimRev_AFFIN table.



Suppress pop-up warnings

DoCmd.SetWarnings False turns off Access’ confirmation prompts (so deletes/inserts don’t pop up messages).



Remove any exact duplicate for the same person/program

It deletes any row where the combined value of [ProgramName] and [AttnTo] equals the combined text of Me.bxAcctName and Me.bxLossCtl1.
In simple terms: “If there’s already a record for this ProgramName and AttnTo combo, delete it first.”



Housekeeping: remove rows with no name

Deletes any record where AttnTo is empty (Null).



Add a new record with the current selection

MyRec.AddNew starts a new row.
It fills fields from the form:

ProgramName ? Me.bxAcctName (the selected program/account name)
RecipCat ? "Risk Solutions Consultant" (a fixed category label)
EMailAddress ? Me.bxLossCtl1.Column(1) (the email from the second column of the bxLossCtl1 control—likely a combo box)
DistVia ? "Email" (distribution method)
AttnTo ? Me.bxLossCtl1 (the display value—likely the person’s name)


MyRec.Update saves the new row.
Closes and clears MyRec.




Repeat for the second table (tblDist_LossRun_AFFIN)
The routine then performs the exact same sequence for tblDist_LossRun_AFFIN:

Open the table.
Turn off warnings (already off).
Delete the duplicate based on [ProgramName] + [AttnTo] matching Me.bxAcctName + Me.bxLossCtl1.
Delete any rows where AttnTo is Null.
Add the new row with the same field values.
Save and close.


What the form controls likely represent

bxAcctName: The selected program/account name.
bxLossCtl1: A person selector (likely a combo box showing names), where:

The visible text is the person’s name (used for AttnTo).
Column(1) holds their email address (used for EMailAddress).




Practical implications & tips

Duplicates handling: By deleting a matching [ProgramName]+[AttnTo] combo before inserting, the tables keep only the latest entry for that pair.
Warnings stay off: DoCmd.SetWarnings False is set but never turned back on here. Consider turning it back on after the operations to restore normal behavior.
Concatenation in the WHERE clause: Matching on [ProgramName]&[AttnTo] works, but it assumes no ambiguous combinations (e.g., "AB" + "C" equals "A" + "BC"). Safer is matching on separate fields (two conditions) to avoid edge cases.
Null cleanup: Automatically removes incomplete rows where AttnTo wasn’t captured.
Error handling: There’s no On Error block—adding one would make this more robust.
Consistency: The logic is duplicated for two different tables to keep Claim Review and Loss Run distributions in sync.

column3: Code executed while opening the form
column11:
When the form opens, it:

Loads all details for the selected Affinity Program from the database.
Displays those details across multiple tabs (General, SHI, Loss Run, Claim Review).
Dynamically enables/disables certain fields based on account status.
Populates monthly reporting history for Claim Reviews and Loss Runs.
Cleans up resources and prepares the form for user interaction.


Step-by-Step Flow
1. Load Selected Program Details

The form takes the program name chosen on the previous search screen and uses it to find the matching record in the tblAcctAffinityProgram table.
It then fills in all the form fields with data from that record:

Program Heading: Program name, onboarding date, branch, notes, account owner, created date/by, total premium, account status, termination details, etc.
General Tab: Business type, service request flags, accommodation details, exceptions.
SHI Tab: SHI completion status and notes.
Loss Run Tab: Notes and distribution frequency.
Claim Review Tab: Notes, frequency, thresholds.
New Fields: Change notes (audit info).




2. Enable/Disable Termination Fields

If the account is Inactive or In Runoff, the termination date and cause fields are enabled for editing.
If the account is Active, those fields are disabled.


3. Load Claim Review Reporting Frequency

Connects to the tblClaimRevFreq_AFFIN table.
If records exist for the program:

Loops through all 12 months (January to December).
For each month:

Retrieves the completion date, report type, and delivery method.
Updates corresponding form fields (e.g., CRSentJan, CRRptJan, CRDelJan).
Sets a checkbox (ckJanCR) to indicate if a report was scheduled for that month.




This gives a full year view of Claim Review reporting activity.


4. Load Loss Run Reporting Frequency

Similar process as Claim Review, but for Loss Run reports:

Connects to tblLossRunFreq_AFFIN.
Loops through all 12 months.
Updates fields like LRSentJan and checkboxes (ckJanLR) for each month.


Provides a month-by-month view of Loss Run reporting.


5. Clean Up and Close Loading Screen

Releases database objects.
Closes a temporary form (frmRunning) used during loading.
Sets focus back to a button on the main form so the user can start interacting.


6. Button to Open Policy Types Form

There’s a separate button (Command225) that, when clicked, opens another form called frmAffinityAccount_PolicyTypes.
If an error occurs while opening, it shows an error message.


In Simple Terms
This function:

Pre-fills the form with all program details.
Shows reporting history for the entire year for Claim Reviews and Loss Runs.
Adapts the form dynamically based on account status.
Provides navigation to related forms.
Ensures everything is ready for the user without manual data entry.

column13:
Part 1 — Confirmation, agent check, and mandatory validations


User confirmation to save/close

Shows a Yes/No dialog using msg, Style, Title.
If Response is vbNo, sets MyString = "No" and exits (no save).



Agent of record check (tblAffinityAgents)

Builds strSQL to look up ProgramName = Me.bxAcctName.
Opens MyRec on results via MyDB (CurrentDb).
If MyRec.EOF is true (no agent found), asks the user:

If Response is vbNo, sets MyString = "No" and exits.
If vbYes, continues without agent.





Mandatory field validations prior to save

Requires Me.bxSince (On Board Date), Me.bxAcctName (Program Name), Me.bxBranch (Branch Office).
If Me.txtAcctStatus = "Inactive", requires Me.bxNotifDt (Notification Date).
Any missing field shows a message, sets focus to the control, and exits.




Part 2 — Save/update core program record (tblAcctAffinityProgram)


Recordset setup

MyDB = CurrentDb; MyRec opened as an editable dynaset on tblAcctAffinityProgram.
DoCmd.SetWarnings False turns off Access prompts temporarily.



Target record and edit

MyRec.FindFirst locates row where ProgramName = Me.bxAcctName.
MyRec.Edit enters edit mode for the found row.



Assign fields from the form (Program Heading)

Writes values from Me.bxAcctName, Me.bxSince, Me.bxBranch, Me.bxAcctNotes, Me.bxSACName1, Me.bxSACName2, Me.bxLossCtl1, Me.bxLossCtl2, Me.bxDateCreated, Me.bxCreatedBy, Me.AcctOwner, Me.cboOB.
“APR 2015” fields: Me.txtTotPrem, Me.txtAcctStatus, Me.txtNumPol, Me.txtTermDt, Me.txtTermCause, Me.bxNotifDt.



Assign fields (Program General tab)

Me.bxBusType, Me.bxServReqYN, Me.bxAccomFormYN, Me.bxAccomType, Me.bxExceptYN, Me.bxExceptType, Me.bxSHIcompYN, Me.bxSHINotes.



Assign fields (Loss Run tab)

Me.bxLossRunNotes, Me.bxLossRunFreq.



Assign fields (Claim Review tab)

Me.bxClaimRevNotes, Me.bxClaimRevFreq, Me.txtCRThresh.



Assign fields (Oct 2019)

Me.txtChangeNotes ? ChangeNotes.



Commit and clean up

MyRec.Update, MyRec.Close, Set MyRec = Nothing.




Part 3 — Monthly frequency tables, cleanup, and navigation
A) Claim Review monthly rows (tblClaimRevFreq_AFFIN)


Setup and reset

MyRec opened on tblClaimRevFreq_AFFIN.
Deletes all rows for ProgramName = Me.bxAcctName to rebuild fresh.



12?month loop (LoopCount 1–12)

Each month: MyRec.AddNew and set:

ProgramName = Me.bxAcctName
MthNum = month number (1–12)
CompDate from Me.CRSentJan/Feb/…/Dec
RptType from Me.CRRptJan/…/Dec
DelivMeth from Me.CRDelJan/…/Dec
CRNumNarr from Me.CRNumNarr_JAN/FEB/…/DEC
RptMth = 1 if ckJanCR/…/ckDecCR is true, else 0


MyRec.Update per month.
Close and release MyRec after the loop.



B) Loss Run monthly rows (tblLossRunFreq_AFFIN)


Setup and reset

MyRec opened on tblLossRunFreq_AFFIN.
Deletes all rows for ProgramName = Me.bxAcctName.



12?month loop (LoopCount 1–12)

Each month: MyRec.AddNew and set:

ProgramName = Me.bxAcctName
MthNum = month number (1–12)
CompDate from Me.LRSentJan/Feb/…/Dec
RptMth = 1 if ckJanLR/…/ckDecLR is true, else 0


MyRec.Update per month.
Close and release MyRec after the loop.



C) Final wrap?up

DoCmd.SetWarnings True turns Access prompts back on.
Closes the current object and frmFindAccount (without saving layout), then opens frmMainMenu.
Exit_btnClose_Click clean exit; Err_btnClose_Click shows Err.Description and resumes to exit.

column5: SELECT tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName AS [Program Name], tblAffinityPolicyType.PolicyType AS [Policy Type], First(tblAffinityAgents.AgentName) AS [Primary Agent], First(tblAffinityAgents.AgentCode) AS [Agent Code] FROM tblAffinityPolicyType LEFT JOIN tblAffinityAgents ON tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName=tblAffinityAgents.ProgramName GROUP BY tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName, tblAffinityPolicyType.PolicyType HAVING (((tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName)=Forms!frmAffinityParent!bxAcctName))

SELECT tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName AS [Program Name], tblAffinityPolicyType.PolicyType AS [Policy Type], First(tblAffinityAgents.AgentName) AS [Primary Agent], First(tblAffinityAgents.AgentCode) AS [Agent Code] FROM tblAffinityPolicyType LEFT JOIN tblAffinityAgents ON tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName=tblAffinityAgents.ProgramName GROUP BY tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName, tblAffinityPolicyType.PolicyType HAVING (((tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName)=Forms!frmAffinityParent!bxAcctName))

SELECT tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName AS [Program Name], tblAffinityPolicyType.PolicyType AS [Policy Type], First(tblAffinityAgents.AgentName) AS [Primary Agent], First(tblAffinityAgents.AgentCode) AS [Agent Code] FROM tblAffinityPolicyType LEFT JOIN tblAffinityAgents ON tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName=tblAffinityAgents.ProgramName GROUP BY tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName, tblAffinityPolicyType.PolicyType HAVING (((tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName)=Forms!frmAffinityParent!bxAcctName))

SELECT tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName AS [Program Name], tblAffinityPolicyType.PolicyType AS [Policy Type], First(tblAffinityAgents.AgentName) AS [Primary Agent], First(tblAffinityAgents.AgentCode) AS [Agent Code] FROM tblAffinityPolicyType LEFT JOIN tblAffinityAgents ON tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName=tblAffinityAgents.ProgramName GROUP BY tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName, tblAffinityPolicyType.PolicyType HAVING (((tblAffinityPolicyType.ProgramName)=Forms!frmAffinityParent!bxAcctName))

Removes duplicates (for the same CustomerNum + AttnTo) and cleans blank names in both tblDistribute_ClaimReview and tblDistribute_LossRun.
Adds a fresh record to both tables with:

Customer: bxCustNum

That’s the full flow—validate, deduplicate, clean, and insert into both distribution tables.
